title: RBA expected to hit millions of Aussies with interest rate pain
text:
H﻿ello and welcome to 9news.com.au's live coverage of today's interest rates decision.

The Reserve Bank of Australia is widely expected to hand down a hike today, bringing the official cash rate up 25 basis points to 3.85 per cent.

However, some economists and traders believe there is a chance Governor Michele Bullock will announce a hold, with the﻿ market pricing in a roughly 70 per cent chance of a rise.

The RBA will hand down its decision at 2.30pm (AEDT), and Bullock will hold her post-meeting press conference at 3.30pm.

READ MORE: Treasurer defends government spending ahead of expected rates hike

READ MORE: Home buyers' budgets could be cut by thousands overnight

READ MORE: 'Cold shower' for mortgage holders: Experts' gloomy rates' forecast

﻿READ MORE: Three things could save Aussies from looming interest rate hell

title: NSW woman left brusied and with brain bleed after e-bike crash
text:
A﻿n elderly woman has been left bruised and with a brain bleed after she was hit by a child on an e-bike.

Robin*, from Balgowlah in Sydney's north, told 2GB's Ben Fordham that she had already spent a week in hospital after she was hit by the bike while she was waiting at a bus shelter.

The NSW woman said she remained in the hospital until her scans were stable﻿.

A﻿n eldery woman has been left brusied and with a brain bleed after she was hit by a child on an e-bike. (2GB)

"I'm feeling a lot ﻿better but I'm still very, very sore and bad headaches," she said.

"I could see this ﻿kid coming, he was going so fast I actually thought he was out of control.

"I was trying to get away from the bus shelter, but before I could move he hit me and sent me flying.

"It was so fast, but ﻿all I know is my head and my hands hit the ground first, because my whole face is purple now.

"﻿My knees and everything, I just went crash bang onto the ground.

"Even the whites of my eyes were black."

Robyn said the e-bike rider did not stop to help her. (Getty)

She said the child on the e-bike didn't stop ﻿to help her, and there was "no sign of him" after she fell to the ground.

However the bus was stopped at the red light and the bus driver got off to help her.

"The bus driver got off and somebody else helped me up," she said.

"I sat in the bus shelter until I stopped shaking and took myself home which was across the road."﻿

She tried to get CCTV from the shop across the road but the bus was parked. She said she wasn't the only one in hospital who had been hit by one.

"When I was ﻿having x-rays, the girl said this is the third e-bike for the day," she said.

"﻿My daughter had her whole arm smashed up, she's had plates and screws in her, that was nine months ago, and she's still having physio trying to get the arm going."

*Name changed at Robin's request.﻿

title: Aussie vaccine trial offers 'glimmer of hope' for kids with brain tumours
text:
A world-first vaccine trial in Australia will treat children with advanced brain tumours using technology from the COVID-19 jab.

The clinical study – led by the University of Queensland and South Australia Health and Medical Research Institute (SAHMRI) – will harness mRNA medicine to encourage the body's immune system to fight cancerous cells.

Each of the vaccines will be personalised using genetic markers, and scientists hope the shots will improve survival rates of childhood brain cancer.

READ MORE: ﻿ Fergie email sparks bombshell Epstein baby claim

The vaccine trial will use mRNA technology, known for the COVID-19 vaccines. (Scimex)

READ MORE: Treasurer defends government spending ahead of expected rates hike ﻿

The four-year trial will be rolled out at eight paediatric hospitals in Queensland, SA, New South Wales, Victoria﻿ and Western Australia later this year.

Young patients with "dismal outlooks" or a survival expectancy of between 12 and 24 months will be eligible for the trial.

This includes children with relapsed and unresponsive high-grade tumours, medulloblastoma, ependymoma, high-grade glioma and newly-diagnosed diffuse midline gliomas.

"This is a new, personalised approach to treating these especially difficult brain cancers that we believe has huge potential," SAHMRI and Adelaide University clinical lead Professor Jordan Hansford said.

"Phase I of the trial will help us determine the safest and most effective dose.

"Phase II will assess how well the treatment works, including whether it slows cancer progression and improves overall survival and quality of life for participating children and their families."

Hansford said half of all screened participants may be suitable for the trial.

Around 70 children from around Australia will take part in the trial over four years.

Professor Brandon Wainwright of UQ's Frazer Institute is the trial's scientific lead. (The University of Queensland)

It takes about eight weeks to develop each vaccine, and each child is given eight shots, two weeks apart, before booster shots later down the track

Personalised mRNA vaccines have already shown promising results in adults with rare and difficult-to-treat cancers, such as pancreatic and melanoma.

﻿The trial will provide a "glimmer of hope" for children with aggressive brain tumours, UQ's Frazer Institute scientific lead Brandon Wainwright explained.

Around 70 children from around Australia will take part in the trial over four years. (iStock)

"After identifying unique cancer markers in each child's tumour using genome sequencing and advanced data analysis, we will select tumour-specific vaccine targets," Wainwright said.

"Customised vaccines for each child will then be manufactured in Queensland by Southern RNA and then sent to the trial sites for dosing.

"We expect to have a customised vaccine ready within about 10 weeks of them enrolling in the trial."

About 40 Australian children die every year of brain cancer, which is the deadliest childhood cancer.

title: Melania Trump's movie bombs hard at the Australian box office
text:
The documentary about Melania Trump which cost Amazon more than a hundred million dollars has bombed at the Australian box office.

Melania debuted on its opening weekend at 31st at the box office, selling just $22,284 worth of tickets.

In its first three days in release, it sold just $675 per screen.

Amazon paid Melania Trump tens of millions of dollars for the rights to her documentary. (AP)

The documentary appeared in the box office list two spots above Dune: Part Two , which was showing on a single screen two years after it was first released.

Topping the box office, horror film Iron Lung debuted to $1.153 million, making $4726 per screen.

Melania , which tells the story of the weeks leading up to the president's inauguration from the perspective of the First Lady , fared much better in the US.

The film debuted in third place with $10 million in takings.

This makes it the highest debut for a documentary in years.

Melania Trump at the premiere of her movie. (AP)

In the UK, the film sold $63,000 worth of tickets, debuting in eighth place. In New Zealand it debuted at 28th with $4647.

But Melania has a steep hill to climb if it intends to be profitable for the studio.

Amazon paid $57 million for the rights to the movie, much of which went into the First Lady's pocket.

It also reportedly spent a further $50 million on promoting the movie.

In order for the movie to be a financial success for Amazon , it would need to have a historic run following its opening weekend.

The audience waits for Melania to begin at a screening in her home country of Slovenia. (AP)

Typically movies need to make more than double their budget in order to turn a profit, given the cinemas themselves take a substantial cut of the ticket sales.

Melania has also shown an enormous divide between critical reception and how general audiences responded.

Critics reviews gathered by Rotten Tomatoes showed just seven per cent of them liked the movie.

Amazon has spent tens of millions of dollars promoting Melania. (Amazon MGM)

By contrast, 98 per cent of audience members on the site said they liked the movie.

The film was directed by Brett Ratner , the Hollywood filmmaker behind blockbuster hits like Red Dragon, X-Men: The Last Stand and the Rush Hour franchise.

Melania is his first movie since six women accused him of sexual misconduct in 2017 .

He is now working on Rush Hour 4 at the behest of Donald Trump.

Melania Trump in the documentary. (Amazon MGM)

title: New capital joins $1 million house club
text:
A new capital has joined the ranks of Australian cities where the average house exceeds $1 million, as property prices continue their stubborn climb nationwide.

The median cost of a standalone home in Perth hit $1,003,804 in January, climbing 1.9 per cent from the previous month, according to Cotality's Home Value Index.

It is the fourth Australian city to reach that benchmark, trailing just behind Brisbane and Canberra where median house prices have crept up to $1,149,589 and $1,033,761 respectively.

Property values in Perth have jumped by 18.5 per cent in the last 12 months, with standalone houses now exceeding $1 million for the first time. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

It comes amid persistent property price rises nationwide, despite renewed cost of living pressures on the eve of a forecast interest rate hike.

The newly released Home Value Index also shows that it is the most affordable properties - those in the lowest quarter of the price range - where prices are rising fastest, in a trend that risks pushing home ownership ever further out of reach for thousands of Australians.

While Sydney remains by far the most unaffordable city for house ownership, with a median price of $1,598,819, growth has slowed to just 0.3 per cent in January.

﻿Nationally, the value of Australian homes (both houses and apartments) rose by 0.8 per cent in January, according to Cotality's Home Value Index - a slight uptick from 0.6 per cent in December. ﻿

Stubbornly high property prices are a fresh blow to prospective home buyers who are bracing for a cut to their borrowing power if the Reserve Bank hikes interest rates tomorrow as forecast.

"Despite the most unaffordable conditions on record in many cities, along with a rebound in cost of living pressures and prospect of a rate hike as early as (tomorrow), we are still seeing a broad-based rise in housing values," Cotality's research director Tim Lawless said.

However, Lawless suggested price rises are likely to ease this year, as demand eased and forecast interest rate hikes limited people's ability to service larger mortgages.

Fewer homes are being put on the market this month compared to the same time last year. (Supplied / Nine)

The number of homes advertised for sale is currently 19﻿ per cent below where it was at this time last year and 25 per cent below the five-year average.

At the same time, the quarterly number of home sales is one per cent higher than a year ago.﻿

Australia's smaller and mid-sized capitals have recorded the biggest jump in property prices, with Perth, Brisbane and Adelaide prices rising by between 1.2 and 2 per cent.

That compares to an incremental creep of just 0.2 and 0.1 per cent respectively for Sydney and Melbourne.﻿

In the past year, Darwin has seen the steepest property price increases, up by almost a fifth (19.7 per cent).

The second-largest increase is in Perth, where combined house and unit prices have risen by 18.5 per cent annually, making it the third most expensive city to buy a property after Sydney and Brisbane.

Sydney and Melbourne properties are up a comparatively ﻿small 6.4 and 5.4 per cent annually.

In worrying news for housing affordability and equality, homes at the most affordable end of the housing market are seeing the largest price hikes.

House values in the lowest quartile rose by 1.3 per cent, compared to just 0.3 per cent rise in the top quartile.﻿

"This trend of stronger growth conditions at lower price points is supported by intense competition for more affordable houses," said Lawless.

"This is where first home buyers, investors and, progressively, mainstream demand is most concentrated."

title: Class action alleges contamination by one of world's biggest goldmines
text:
Landowners living near one of the world's biggest goldmines in central west NSW have launched an environmental class action alleging contamination of more than 2,000 properties.

Lawyers for the claimants allege arsenic, heavy metals and forever chemicals known as PFAS have travelled from Newmont's Cadia goldmine onto properties in a 17-kilometre radius.

The EPA launched criminal proceedings against Newcrest Mining in the Land and Environment Court. (Supplied: Newcrest)

"This case follows … three years of investigation by the community, [looking] at the impact upon their properties from the dust and water pollution, " principal lawyer Oliver Gayner said.

Mr Gayner said the community felt it had "no choice" other than to litigate.

"They've communicated those science-based results to the mine operator and sought a collaborative process to try and resolve the pollution issues, but those requests have been refused," he said.

Water scientist Dr Ian Wright has contributed his expertise to the community's testing program. (ABC Central West: Micaela Hambrett)

Community members are seeking compensation from the mining giant, saying the pollution has damaged their property values through a "toxic trifecta" of air, surface and groundwater pollution.

They are also seeking an injunction to restrain further pollution from the Cadia site, which has a production rate of more than 30 million tonnes of ore a year.

"Success for us is not about money, it will be measured by the change in operations at Cadia," Mr Gayner said.

In a statement, Newmont Cadia confirmed it had been served with proceedings in the Supreme Court of NSW and would "respond through the appropriate legal processes".

"As the matter is before court, it is not appropriate to comment further at this time," the statement read.

Dust up

Residents of the Cadia and Errowanbang valleys near Orange flagged pollution concerns with the NSW Environment Protection Authority (EPA) in 2018, after the mine's tailings dam wall collapsed.

Jann Harries, who lives 2 kilometres from the mine's boundary, said the impact of the structural failure was obvious.

"Everything was covered in off-white dust, day in, day out," Ms Harries said.

"It had that taste and smell, if I breathed it in, I'd start coughing."

A photograph taken at Jann Harries fence line during a dust event in May, 2023. (Supplied: Cadia Community Sustainability Network)

Concerns were raised again after extractor fans over an underground crusher were found to be blasting unfiltered dust into the atmosphere at 18 times the legal limit.

Drinking water tanks on neighbouring properties were subsequently found to contain heavy metals, including lead.

Future implications

The class action is being bankrolled by UK litigation fund Aristata, whose executives travelled from London to visit allegedly affected farms last year.

In a statement, head of portfolio management, Michael Hartridge, called the case "important", saying it supported the "UN's sustainable development goals".

Claimants said they were not arguing the mine should be shut down, acknowledging its role in the region's economy.

However, they claim the current operating rate is not sustainable for the health of their own interests.

Lawyer Oliver Gayner says the class action may end up being a test case for regulators. (ABC Central West: Micaela Hambrett)

Mr Gayner said the case was unusual because it was being bought by people with similarly valuable assets to protect.

"What's unusual is the close juxtaposition of a mine within an [organised and determined] community, with farmland and residential properties which are high value," he said.

"These people want to protect their interests now and for the future."

Court history

In 2023, Newmont pleaded guilty in the Land and Environment Court to three counts of air pollution and was fined $350,000.

Two additional charges were dropped in exchange for the mine installing five new dust monitors in 2024.

That same year, farmers on the mine's southern border reported slabs of white foam appearing on the Belubula River, an important source of irrigation for the region.

Foam was recorded in the Belubula River in July 2024. (Supplied: Cadia Community Sustainability Network)

Laboratory tests revealed the foam was predominantly PFOS, a synthetic chemical used in a variety of industrial applications, including firefighting.

A year-long sampling program by the Environment Protection Authority established PFAS was present in the Upper Belubula River catchment at 16 sites, including the Blayney tip, landscape supplier ANL and Cadia, but the risk was low for livestock and the environment.

The EPA later banned fishing in the Belubula and erected warning signs after testing revealed the flesh of some fish species contained 40 times the daily intake limit for PFOS.

A hearing has been directed for March.

title: Major potato supplier Zerella plans new NT farm
text:
A potato supplier for major supermarkets and chip brands hopes to start operations in the Northern Territory which would mark the return of the sector after several decades.

Zerella Holdings has applied to clear about 210 hectares of vegetation on its Eagle Park property outside the town of Katherine, south of Darwin, for irrigated potato production and associated infrastructure.

The farm would produce seed potato, a tuber used to grow the harvestable version of the crop, for Zerella's 50,000-hectare operation in the Mallee region of South Austalia.

It is understood if the venture succeeds it would be the first commercial potato production in the Top End for about 20 years.

One of the properties owned by Zerella Holdings. (Supplied)

General manager Renee Pye said trials had identified the region, renowned for its mango and cattle sectors, as ideal for taking pressure off their other farms further south.

"The Katherine operation is really just to add another rotation for us with seed so we can move the process along at a better rate," she said.

"[Conditions] are not good when it comes to the wet season, so that's not when we are planning on planting and harvesting. We're trying to make sure that we hit that window of your dry season."

She said Zerella hoped to start planting in April, but a new shed, cool room and power upgrades would need to be completed first.

Ms Pye said rumours about the plan had circulated throughout the NT's agricultural community as potatoes had not been cultivated at a commercial scale in the region for many years.

"There's a lot of questions being asked because obviously potatoes haven't been grown in the Northern Territory for a long time," she said.

" There's been a few goes across the last 20 years. We're committed to it and it worked the first year, so we're keen to see it through. "

Previous ventures too expensive

Mike Braun grows cut flowers in Darwin's rural area and tried his hand at potatoes in the late 1990s.

Mike Braun pictured with his freshly-cut Heliconias. (ABC Rural: Lisa Herbert)

He said the dry season provided suitable conditions for the crop but he could not get a good price and eventually moved his business away from potatoes.

"I had some success and I thought I might do it on a bigger scale," he said.

"[But] there's potato growers all over the country, even up north in the Atherton Tablelands in Queensland. So the market was really oversupplied.

"Looking back at my fertiliser cost and water and so on I thought it might not be viable. So I gave it up after a few years."

title: Sydney's maritime history faces uncertain future amid rezoning plan
text:
The future of some of Australia's oldest ships is uncertain as harbour leases near expiration and development pressure comes to bear.

Sydney Heritage Fleet maintains and restores some of Sydney's oldest marine vessels, including the James Craig tall ship built in 1884, the 1927 John Oxley steamship and the 1912 Kanangra Sydney ferry.

The Rozelle shipyard says its lease on the government-owned land is up in 2028. Vice-president Brett Smith is concerned the organisation may be left without a home if the land is acquired amid Bays West transport oriented development (TOD) rezoning.

Sydney Heritage Fleet workers restore and maintain some of the city's oldest vessels. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

Mr Smith says there is nowhere else in Sydney that could accommodate the fleet.

"There's nowhere left because it's all been developed and sold off," he said.

"It's not just waterfrontage [we need] — it has to be waterfrontage in an area where you can make a bit of noise."

"If they did come to us and say, 'Sorry, you're out in '28', we don't know where we're going to go."

Brett Smith from Sydney Heritage Fleet says there are no suitable alternatives to the Rozelle Bay site. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

Across a 10-lane highway connecting the city's Inner West to the Anzac Bridge is the site of the future Bays Metro station, which is due to be completed in 2032.

Plans for the development include rezoning land for new homes within 1,200 metres of the station.

A Department of Planning, Housing and Infrastructure website said the the plan would be made public by 2025 but that date has been missed.

A NSW planning department spokesperson said the plan was subject to a review of the working port by the state's Cabinet Office.

The volunteer-run Sydney Heritage Fleet fixes up century-old ships. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

Mr Smith says moving the working port for housing will make repair and maintenance jobs in Sydney Harbour more expensive.

"If the right balance isn't struck on the housing versus commercial-industrial use of this land … I know that governments will look back and really regret that," he said.

"The the only way to maintain things in and around the harbour will be to bring things in from other ports via barges.

"There'll be extra costs involved in that, all sorts of issues with weather, when you can't actually do those sorts of transport work."

The shipyards at Rozelle Bay sit close to the future metro station. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

Uncertainty at working port

Marine companies based at Rozelle Bay say they have leases until 2028 and are also facing an uncertain future.

Clement Marine Constructions director Richard Oppedisano says he does not know whether the outfit will be able to continue to do emergency work on ferry wharves.

"I'm not sure if we can even carry out the work that we do now and meet our obligations under our contracts, because part of those obligations are we've got time limits on how long it takes us to get the equipment to the job site," he said.

A metro station is planned for the Bays West precinct to connect open spaces and social infrastructure. (Supplied: Infrastructure NSW)

Mr Oppedisano said the company had not had alternative locations proposed by the state government.

Brad Hosemans from Polaris Marine, a maintenance contractor for Transport for NSW, wrote a submission during the Bays station consultation process in which he said there was no other site on the harbour that would allow the company to continue at the same scale.

"That is because no such site exists," he said.

"The combination of deep-water access, industrial zoning, sufficient land area, and continuous navigational access does not exist elsewhere in the harbour."

Mr Hosemans rejected the idea of moving to Port Botany or Port Kembla, south of Wollongong, as it would make the day-to-day maintenance of harbour assets untenable.

Cabinet review of port ongoing

Despite the planning department website stating the Bays West TOD rezoning plan would be publicly available in 2025, they have not been published.

Bays West is one of eight TOD precincts in Sydney and is the only one that does not have a finalisation report exhibited.

The website states that the Bays West TOD rezoning will track on a different timeline due to the need to "resolve working harbour and ports uses".

A spokesperson for the Department of Planning, Housing and Infrastructure said the rezoning proposal was subject to a review led by the Cabinet Office.

The review is examining the potential of housing coexisting with the working port, according to a 2025 Transport for NSW report.

"The review has involved extensive consultation with stakeholders, including leaseholders operating out of the precinct," the spokesperson said.

"No decision has been made on the future of the precinct. The NSW government will have more to say once it has considered the findings of the review."

The precinct includes parts of the working harbour at Glebe Island in White Bay, which handles large amounts of the state's cement, sugar, salt and gypsum.

title: Nusantara Beat to bring 'psychedelic' take on Indonesian folk music to WOMADelaide
text:
An Amsterdam-based band is bringing its psychedelic take on traditional Indonesian music to Australia for the first time in March.

Nusantara Beat topped the Transglobal World Music Chart in January and is scheduled to play in South Australia at world music, art and dance festival WOMADelaide.

All members of the Dutch band have Indonesian ancestry, and guitarist Jordy Sanger said they decided to dive into their roots through music.

30 years of Womadelaide for a tree Womadelaide has grown in 30 years from small beginnings in Adelaide's Botanic Park, but so too have the trees its musical notes have bounced about.

"Psychedelic music, for me, is where your thoughts float away, not being afraid of making bold choices in a sonic way, trying to connect different harmonic realms, like a trip," Sanger said.

"And indeed, it's so much fun to combine that with traditional Indonesian music and instruments.

" The traditional instruments can make the music sound very dangerous … we love that. "

Sanger said everyone in the six-piece band had sought to discover their ancestry.

Jordy Sanger says it felt "unreal" to hit number one on the Transglobal World Music Chart. (Instagram: @nusantara_beat)

"When I was a kid and living in the east of the Netherlands, all my friends were white; I was the only brown kid at school," Sanger said.

"So when I looked in the mirror, I always saw something different compared with my local environment and that was fine. I experienced it as something rather neutral.

"But when I grew older, I became more curious about my roots and ancestry, especially in my late 20s."

Live music is integral to Indonesian culture — in traditional music settings, but also in guitar-based rock'n'roll that is exceptionally popular among locals.

"Live music runs in their veins," Sanger said.

"In the Netherlands, almost every Indonesian-descended person I know, knows how to play guitar."

He said it felt very "exciting to discover 60s and 70s Indonesian pop music".

Nusantara Beat is fronted by vocalist Megan de Klerk. (Instagram: @nusantara_beat)

"Although I don't understand all the words immediately, the music and the words do resonate with me," he said.

Sanger also studied the compositional aspect of Indonesian music.

This included the scales and harmony used in traditional Indonesian music and Sunda pop [Sundanese popular music].

In what he described as a generally unplanned approach, the band acquired some traditional instruments like gamelan gangsa (metallophones), kecapi, kendang, ceng-cengs and gongs.

"The gangsa and gongs were sampled and loaded into samplers," he said.

"The kecapi was played by Rouzy [Portier]. It's a sitar-ish instrument. Kendang is a drum from Java or Bali.

"Ceng-cengs are thick, brass cymbals you hit against each other and, together with the gongs, they were played by Gino [Groeneveld], our percussionist."

The result is a highly rhythmic sound, a mix of western electric guitar licks and Indonesian folk, and fun, playful grooves.

Topping global chart

Nusantara Beat in January hit number one on the Transglobal World Music Chart, which is ranked by an international panel of music critics.

It makes its choices based on merit rather than popularity, big productions or record sales, and disbands with geographical barriers.

Sanger said it felt a bit "unreal" for a band that did not follow the charts.

"But when we actually looked at the chart and saw the other artists on it, it felt very special," he said.

" For us, it mostly feel like encouragement, something like, 'OK, this strange mix of Indonesian roots and psych folk actually connects with people far outside of our own bubble. "

They have also built a following in Indonesia.

"On Instagram, about 70 per cent of our following is from Indonesia," Sanger said.

"We've been touring in Indonesia twice. We haven't played a show in Bali — yet, please invite us."

Sanger also met Indonesian family for the first time while touring there in 2024.

"That was mental. It felt like I'd known them for my whole life," he said.

"The immediate warmth is, for me, very special."

Nusantara Beat will play two sets at WOMADelaide.

Sanger said audiences could expect to hear "Indonesian psych folk tunes served with good vibes and quite possibly jetlag".

title: Wallabies Rugby World Cup draw revealed ahead of home tournament
text:
Australia's home Rugby World Cup campaign will kick off against debutants Hong Kong China rather than bitter rivals New Zealand, who also feature in the same pool.

Chile return for a second World Cup to round out Pool A at next year's hotly anticipated tournament, the first hosted in Australia since 2003.

It will be Australia's first match against the South American nation.

"It's incredibly exciting to have the schedule locked in for the Wallabies' pool fixtures, ahead of what's going to be a truly special tournament here in Australia next year," Rugby Australia chief executive Phil Waugh said.

The Wallabies will be rated favourites alongside the All Blacks, second on the World Rugby rankings, to finish in the top two of Pool A and advance to the knockout stage.

Four of the six third-placed teams from the group stage will also progress.

Should Australia place second in their pool, they will face the Pool F runners-up — one of England, Wales, Tonga and Zimbabwe — for their first knockout clash.

Win their pool, and Australia would face the third-placed team from Pool C, E or F in the round of 16.

Perth will host Australia's first pool match on October 1 next year, before the All Blacks clash in Sydney on October 9, then the match against Chile on October 16 in Brisbane.

2027 Rugby World Cup Pools

Pool A: New Zealand, Australia, Chile, Hong Kong

Pool B: South Africa, Italy, Georgia, Romania

Pool C: Argentina, Fiji, Spain, Canada

Pool D: Ireland, Scotland, Uruguay, Portugal

Pool E: France, Japan, USA, Samoa

Pool F: England, Wales, Tonga, Zimbabwe

AAP

title: Sam Kerr is back for the Asian Cup after winning it as a teenager
text:
Sam Kerr was just 16 when Australia last won soccer's Women's Asian Cup in 2010, the tournament in which she also scored her first international goal.

In the intervening 16 years, the Matildas have reached the tournament's final twice, losing both times to Japan, as well as taking part in three Olympics and four Women's World Cups.

But another major title has eluded a side that reached as high as fourth in the world.

"Sixteen years ago seems crazy. It feels like yesterday," Kerr told ABC Perth.

"I thought I would win many more. I think it shows how hard it is to win the Asian Cup and the importance of the tournament."

The Matildas had joy and relief after beating North Korea on penalties in the final of the Women's Asia Cup in Chengdu in 2010. (Getty Images: Visual China Group)

Kerr herself has experienced both the highs and lows professionally, signing with Chelsea in 2020 and winning five consecutive FA Women's Super League titles as well as three Women's FA Cups.

But she has also endured a torrid 20 months after suffering a knee injury and an ACL injury during a training camp in late 2023 and early 2024.

After 637 days out of the game, Kerr returned for Chelsea last September and scored 13 minutes after coming off the bench.

It's been a steady build since then.

"I'm playing more minutes now. I feel like I'm hitting my stride," the 32-year-old said.

"I knew it would be a long process, and I've been back for about four or five months now, and every week, honestly, I feel better."

Sam Kerr has scored some memorable goals for the Matildas, including this stunner against England at the 2023 World Cup. (AAP Image: Dan Himbrechts)

Australia will host the Asian Cup in March, with the Matildas playing the Philippines in Perth to open the tournament, a side they thrashed 8-0 at Perth Stadium in 2023.

"We played really well last time at Perth. It was in front of a sold-out stadium, so there was a real buzz around it," Kerr said.

"Sixteen years ago at the last Asian Cup, I don't think there was many people around the country watching.

"But to be a part of the change of women's football in the last four to five years has been incredible.

Sam Kerr has scored 62 times for the Matildas, making her a favourite among fans (AAP Image/Mark Evans)

"I think this moment in time will be looked back on forever as the time that women's football changed in Australia and around the world."

Kerr's return to the Matildas came months after the appointment of Joe Montemurro as coach.

The former midfielder coached Arsenal, Juventus and Lyon's women's sides to titles, and has enjoyed a solid start with Australia winning five of the eight games he's taken charge of.

"(Montemurro) wants to play a certain style of football, which has been really clear," Kerr said of the national side's new manager.

"I think when you have a clear message and a clear identity as a team, it's been really easy to just [get] everyone focus on themselves, train on themselves, and make sure we're at our best physically and mentally.

"It's nice to have an Aussie in there. I think it just hits home when you've got an Aussie coach coaching you.

"He's a top coach, but he's been really good for the group off the pitch too."

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

title: Locals don't want tourists to stop visiting, but 'beg' them to look after beach
text:
About 450 kilometres south of Perth on a remote stretch of pristine beach, 50 or so people spent their Saturday laying out weed matting and dragging around tree branches.

The volunteers, aged from eight to 88, are part of Friends of Boat Harbour, a community-led group trying to mend the damage caused by tourists who descend on their local beach each summer.

Some of the volunteers were as young as eight. (Supplied: Benita Cattalini)

"It's a beautiful spot to come down to and go for a bit of a walk," Shire of Denmark revegetation officer Anais Schneider said.

"Some people come to fish, some people come to swim. It's a very rugged landscape and there's quite a few plants here that I have seen nowhere else in Denmark, so it's quite a unique little spot."

Destroyed by tourism

But the beach's beauty is also its undoing, with the influx of visitors — and their four-wheel drives — causing significant damage to the dunes.

"The Great Southern [region] is iconic now [and considered] some of the best beaches in Australia. If you can drive a car you can get here," volunteer Liz Jack said.

The beach, accessible only by a four-wheel drive track, is a popular spot. (ABC Great Southern: Mark Bennett)

"And there isn't anybody monitoring whether you're camping out here or not because we don't have enough resources.

"We're not monitoring the impact of tourism on local communities sufficiently from an environmental perspective and a community-impact perspective.

" It's all about money, it's all about markets, it's all about economic input into the state, [which are] important — don't get me wrong — but this is the cost. "

Volunteer Benita Cattalini said the issue was largely a product of ignorance, with drivers unaware that when they left the designated track, they could be causing irreparable damage.

"It's the keen drivers of four-wheel drives and motorbikes that like to come out, which is great, but … we beg of them, please don't drive on the sand dunes," she said.

Volunteers roll out weed mats. (Supplied: Benita Cattalini)

Ms Cattalini said the materials alone for that stage of the revegetation had cost more than $20,000, and that was not counting the habitat loss.

"Just over there to my left, there's plants that take 100 years to cover those rocks, and if people drive over the top of them, they don't recover," she said.

Volunteers fighting back

The Friends of Boat Harbour volunteers were able to complete stage one of the rehabilitation project.

Their efforts have paved the way for the planting of about 2,500 native plants, currently held in the Shire of Denmark's nursery, once the wet weather arrives in autumn.

Volunteers use native brush cuttings gathered from nearby bush to help stabilise the sand. (Supplied: Benita Cattalini)

"I've also taken about 1,000 cuttings, so we're trying to use endemic plants [from the area] that have the best chance of success because they're used to the harsh conditions," Ms Schneider said.

" We'll hopefully — over the next couple of years — see this area [get] back to how it's supposed to look. "

The project, supported by CoastWA grants and the Shire of Denmark, forms part of the shire's coastal management plan for areas with a high risk of erosion.

The shire is also trialling a closure of the headland.

Volunteers say education is the key to changing behaviour. (ABC Great Southern: Mark Bennett)

Shire of Denmark director of infrastructure and assets, Rob Westerberg, said it was a pristine piece of land.

"Our environmental groups are very passionate — and so is the Shire of Denmark — in trying to maintain it for future generations," he said.

Despite their fears for the landscape, the locals remained welcoming.

"We're not trying to stop people coming here, we just want to look after it so it's here forever," Ms Cattalini said.

title: Victorian woman 'heartbroken' after fertility surgery delayed again
text:
Alli, who requested her surname be withheld for privacy reasons, wants to have a baby but is facing months of "heartbreaking" surgery delays while waiting for treatment of suspected endometriosis.

Facing extreme pain, the Victorian woman in her 30s was told by the Ballarat Base Hospital that it was unable to set a date for her laparoscopy due to ongoing strikes across the state.

But for Alli, time is precious.

She opted to go through a private surgeon to help speed up the process, but it has made no difference.

"They [Ballarat Base] said since December they've had these strikes, and they're only assessing category 1 patients," she said.

" So I don't make the cut, and they have absolutely no idea when they'll be back up and running. "

Alli said she was frustrated and frightened.

"I don't know what state my reproductive organs are in, so I'm too scared to try [to get pregnant]," she said.

"I'm also too scared to come off birth control now because that's the only little bit of pain relief that I get."

In a statement, Grampians Health said it was "working hard to ensure elective surgeries can continue while respecting the rights of our colleagues who are taking protected industrial action".

"We acknowledge the ongoing EBA negotiations and the Fair Work process, and we value the important contribution of our staff," a spokesperson said.

More than 10,000 health workers have taken part in strike action. (ABC News: Rochelle Kirkham)

The Health Workers Union Victoria said more than 10,000 workers have taken part in strike action at 82 services across the state, over a pay dispute that has dragged on for more than 14 months.

Lead organiser Jake McGuinness said this pay dispute relates to everybody in the hospital system, apart from the doctors, nurses and paramedics.

"Our theatre and instrument technicians, our orderlies, our allied health assistants and our essential support services … and our admin teams," he said.

Mr McGuinness said after two strikes and significant work bans since December, a deal had still not been made with the state government.

"Over the last week and a half, I've had what I thought were positive discussions with the government," Mr McGuiness said.

"We had come to a sort of verbal, informal agreement that it would be a two-year deal, 5 per cent increases in each of those years; there was still a discussion point around back pay.

" Despite our week of conversations, the offer they put [down] didn't resemble the deal that we had reached … they stretched the deal to three years. "

Mr McGuiness said after months of pain for patients and healthcare workers, the state government was yet to make an offer that at least met inflation.

'A slap in the face'

"We gave them a deadline for the month of February; we didn't want to extend," Mr McGuinness said.

Jake McGuinness says strike action will continue for the month of February. (Supplied: Jake McGuinness)

" But after this insulting offer and a slap in the face, we've been given no choice but to extend our work bans through the month of February. "

In Victoria, category 2 and 3 surgeries are considered elective — that is, semi-urgent treatment that "should" be done within 90 days.

It can include heart valve replacements, orthopaedic procedures and fractures.

These elective surgeries will be paused at a number of hospitals during the strikes.

Alli said the categorisation system for surgeries needed to be reassessed.

"For me, this is pretty important because we don't know how severe it is until we're in there [surgery]," she said.

" What if this longer wait is restricting my chances of being able to have children in the future? "

A Victorian government spokesperson said it would always back its "dedicated healthcare workforce and the extraordinary care they provide to Victorians who need it most".

"The Victorian Hospitals Industrial Association continues to negotiate with the Health Workers Union with assistance from the Fair Work Commission," the spokesperson said.

title: Two mothers sit inside tennis's top 10 rankings for the first time
text:
Two mothers are simultaneously inside the women's tennis top 10 rankings for the first time, as the governing body hails the success of initiatives to keep top players in the sport.

The latest rankings from the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) have Switzerland's Belinda Bencic ranked ninth and Ukrainian Elina Svitolina 10th, the first time two mothers have been in the top 10 at the same time.

Bencic, who has been ranked as high as world number four, returned to the top 10 in mid-January for the first time after the birth of her daughter in 2023.

The Swiss star has now been joined by Svitolina, who returns to the top 10 on the back of a semifinal run at last month's Australian Open in Melbourne.

The historic first is being touted as a success by the WTA, which has made efforts in recent years to help players maintain their professional careers and become parents.

Belinda Bencic returned to the world's top 10 in mid-January for the first time since giving birth to her daughter in 2023. (Reuters: Imagn Images/Mike Frey)

Last year, the WTA announced a maternity fund, while both Bencic and Svitolina have been aided by the WTA's Special Ranking Rule for returning mothers, the governing body said.

"Two mothers ranked inside the WTA Top 10 for the first time is an incredible moment for tennis and for women's sport," WTA chief executive Portia Archer said.

"Not only does this highlight the exceptional achievements of Belinda and Elina, it reaffirms the WTA's commitment to creating an environment where mothers can continue to compete and succeed, at the very highest level of sport — or any profession."

Bencic was the 10th seed at last month's Australian Open, but suffered an upset loss in the second round to Czech outsider Nikola Bartůňková.

Rybakina proves she is no one-hit wonder with AO title A consistent and composed Elena Rybakina claims her maiden Australian Open title by beating world number one Aryna Sabalenka in a thriller three years after her breakout Wimbledon win.

Despite that disappointment, Bencic actually rose one spot in the latest rankings.

"Coming back to the WTA Top 10 one year after returning to competition after maternity leave is something I am incredibly proud of," the Swiss said.

"Very few people know or have experienced how difficult that journey is, but my family, my team and I have put all of our energy, work and dedication into it to accomplish this goal."

Svitolina's return to the top 10 comes off the back of a magnificent performance at Melbourne Park, reaching the semifinal of the grand slam event.

The Ukrainian beat fellow top 10 players Coco Gauff and Mirra Andreeva in the tournament.

"It's a dream to return to the WTA Top 10 and doing it as a mother means so much to me," the world number 10 said.

"I'm proud of my fight and resilience and I can't thank the fans enough for their incredible support."

Meanwhile, Australian Maya Joint has entered the WTA's top 30 for the first time in her career.

Despite falling in the first round of her home slam to Czech player Tereza Valentová at Melbourne Park, the 19-year-old has moved up to a career-high number 29 in the latest ranking release.

Elena Rybakina has risen to number three in the world, up two places, after defeating world number one Aryna Sabalenka to claim the Australian Open title.

title: How James Valentine's creative radio style could 'lift the mood of a city'
text:
Listeners and former colleagues of retiring ABC Radio Sydney presenter James Valentine are paying tribute to his humour, creativity and warmth on air.

They were shocked and saddened by the veteran broadcaster's announcement yesterday that he was retiring due to cancer.

Valentine has hosted Afternoons for more than 20 years, but has been off the air since June after he was diagnosed with omentum cancer affecting a layer of tissue over the stomach and intestines.

Loading...

Yesterday, he said he had made the sad decision to let someone else "have a go at this marvellous shift".

"I need to focus on getting better, on being with family and friends and making sure that I'm giving my health my best shot," he told listeners.

Former ABC Radio Sydney Drive presenter Richard Glover said Valentine made people feel proud to be a Sydneysider.

"I can't think of anybody else who really lifted the mood of a city over such a long time as James did," Glover said.

"It was a daily effort to get people to concentrate on life, ordinary life, and how important and beautiful it is, and he did that every day for 20 years."

Valentine often challenged his audience to get creative by writing poems, plays or even to come up with satirical proposals for new Sydney infrastructure.

Richard Glover and James Valentine became close friends during their more than 20 years at ABC Radio Sydney. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

"So you end up sitting, listening to radio, thinking, 'Gee, Sydneysiders are funny and lively and witty and gorgeous,'" Glover said.

"He brought that out in people."

Valentine conducted his audience like a 'wonderful orchestra'

For more than 20 years, the two broadcasters would chat for 10 minutes on air as Valentine wrapped up his Afternoons program and handed over the mic.

"He was incredibly creative … I had complete confidence that I could start off in the oddest of places, and he'd find us somewhere amusing to go," Glover said.

While many treat talkback radio as an opportunity for listeners to give their opinion on politics, Valentine had a different approach, focusing on social quirks or letting his audience air their petty grievances.

"I think James understood that it could be something a lot more nourishing and certainly a lot more entertaining if you actually asked about their lives," Glover said.

A talented saxophonist, Valentine's musical training bled into his broadcasting style.

"He ended up really training his audience to be the most wonderful orchestra, and he was the conductor."

James Valentine was a master of talkback radio, encouraging listeners to tell stories and get creative. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

Former ABC Radio Sydney manager Peter Wall, who hired Valentine in the early 1990s, said he could tell he was a natural in the studio from his first shift.

"When you listen to the first hour, you punch the air and you know that you're happy with what you got — that's what I did with him," he said.

What separated Valentine from his peers was the "looseness" he projected on the airwaves.

"Some of those people just have this thing which breaks through. They manage to stay themselves, notwithstanding the pressures on them … he was one of those special people on radio."

ABC managing director Hugh Marks described Valentine as "one of the great creative forces in Australian broadcasting".

"He has an extraordinary gift for turning everyday moments into joyful, smart and surprising radio, and the connection he has built with his audience over decades simply cannot be overstated," he said.

"We're proud to celebrate everything he has brought to the ABC, and we wish him strength and support as he focuses on his health."

Listeners will have a chance to enjoy Valentine's most memorable moments with a special retrospective that will air on Friday, showcasing the best of Valentine's past programs.

Callers thank Valentine for bringing joy to dull days

Hundreds of listeners flooded the text line, thanking Valentine for his work over the years and wishing him well as he dealt with cancer.

In March 2024, Valentine announced his initial diagnosis of oesophageal cancer and took a leave of absence to receive treatment.

Valentine returned to the program later that year, hosting Afternoons until June 2025, when the new tumours were discovered.

James Valentine, who is a talented jazz musician, is also stepping away from his ABC Jazz program Upbeat. (Supplied: James Valentine)

Long-time listener Jacqueline said she was gutted Valentine was not returning.

"James Valentine turned me into a serial pest. I just couldn't resist his segments. He's kept me company through parental leave, through boring days during lockdown when I was living alone. I'm so sorry to hear he's not coming back. He's brought so much joy to all of us."

Listeners praised his welcoming, warm and kind style.

"No affectation, no feigned tolerance, it was legit," Sarah said.

Many were fans of Valentine's This is What I Live With talkback segment, which allowed people to vent about their partner's foibles.

Tony described him as a free marriage counsellor while Louise credited the segment with helping keep couples together.

"I think it's probably helped normalise some of the madness of our pairings … sometimes it's those little quirky things that really irritate people more than important things," he said.

Valentine could also handle serious events, with Jill praising his coverage of the shootings at a Christchurch mosque in 2019.

"He was rightly shocked and horrified, but equally full of compassion and full of empathy. It was just a time where I felt we really need that, and I really will miss him in the afternoon," she said.

James O'Loghlin is filling in as host of Afternoons, but a permanent replacement has yet to be announced.

title: How Queenslanders can experience ‘once-in-a-generation opportunity’
text:
Wallabies halfback Tate McDermott says incoming national coach Les Kiss has enough time to transform Australia into a Rugby World Cup contender, as the schedule for the 2027 showcase on home soil has been revealed.

Queensland has been locked in for 14 fixtures across the six-week tournament – 10 in Brisbane and four in Townsville.

The Wallabies failed to make it out of the group stages for the first time in their history at the last World Cup, leading to Eddie Jones’ departure as head coach.

Tate McDermott’s hamstring injury is expected to force him to miss a large chunk of the Queensland Reds’ preseason. Credit: Getty Images

title: Missing link in riverside path reopens after three years
text:
Advertisement

NationalQueenslandCity life Missing link in riverside path reopens after three years Brittney Deguara February 3, 2026 — 1:07pm Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

A key section of Brisbane’s Riverwalk has reopened, marking a milestone for the city and the revitalisation of the flood-prone CBD stretch. With the backdrop of the Story Bridge, the ribbon was cut on Tuesday by Lord Mayor Adrian Schrinner and representatives of Dexus to officially open the Riverwalk following a three-year, $42 million transformation. The 256-metre stretch from Charlotte Street to Alice Street creates a continuous walking and cycling route from the Story Bridge at Howard Smith Wharves to the Botanic Gardens. Lord Mayor Adrian Schrinner was among the group officially reopening the Riverwalk on Tuesday. Brittney Deguara “You couldn’t imagine Brisbane without the Riverwalk, just like you couldn’t imagine Brisbane without the CityCats and the Story Bridge,” Schrinner said.

Advertisement

He said the council contributed $22 million to the project to upgrade it from a narrow section of path to the wide, flood-resilient promenade, but the “lion’s share” came from Dexus. “This is the section that I have no doubt tourists in 2032 will be flocking to as this whole precinct is activated. This is about making sure that Brisbane embraces its river,” Schrinner said. He said ratepayers were getting “bang for their buck” through the funding partnership with Dexus, and that paying for the project in full would have cost the council tens of millions of dollars. The section has been fenced off since 2023, while work was done at the multibillion-dollar Waterfront Brisbane site, which will boast retail tenancies.

Advertisement

The entire project was scheduled to open in 2027, but was delayed last year owing to construction complexities and bad weather. “For [Dexus] to keep ploughing ahead and delivering this great outcome against the odds is a fantastic outcome,” Schrinner said. Schrinner walking the new path with Dexus chief executive Ross Du Vernet and project director for Waterfront Brisbane Matthew Beasley. Brittney Deguara “I’m more interested in what it does for the community rather than whether there [were] a few delays suffered. “For generations to come, people will forget about the extra few months it took, and they’ll remember the great outcome that’s been delivered.”

Advertisement

Locals Wayne and Cathy Jeffries were among the first pedestrians to walk along the new path. “I think after the floods they had to do something to bring it back, and looking forward, we’ve got the Olympic Games coming up, so you’ve got to make it look impressive for all the overseas guests,” Wayne said. Wayne and Cathy Jeffries said they would use the walkway every couple of months when they ventured into the city. Brittney Deguara “It’s great to see Brisbane progress and the new Kangaroo Point Bridge as well, and lovely new restaurants around the city, Queen’s Wharf ... it is the place to be,” Cathy added. The passage has been rebuilt with new paths and banisters, and three local street artists painted a Brisbane-themed mural at the start of the walkway in three days.

Advertisement

“It’s a great aquatic theme, which is appropriate for a river city and a city based on Moreton Bay,” Schrinner said. Waterfront Brisbane will eventually comprise two new office towers, shops, restaurants and public space. The aquatic-themed mural at Brisbane’s Riverwalk took just three days to complete. Brittney Deguara It is expected to be ready in late 2028, with construction costs totalling an estimated $2.5 billion. With William Davis Start the day with a summary of the day’s most important and interesting stories, analysis and insights. Sign up for our Morning Edition newsletter.

title: ASX jumps ahead of RBA rates call; Musk merges xAI, SpaceX to create $1.8 trillion giant
text:
Advertisement

Updated BusinessMarketsWorld markets ASX jumps ahead of RBA rates call; Musk merges xAI, SpaceX to create $1.8 trillion giant Staff reporter Updated February 3, 2026 — 12:51pm ,first published February 3, 2026 — 5:16am Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

The Australian sharemarket has surged higher with mining stocks recovering some of Monday’s losses in early trade, while investors are eagerly awaiting the RBA’s decision on interest rates this afternoon. The S&P/ASX 200 was up 102.8 points, or 1.2 per cent, at 8881.4 at 10.37am AEDT, with 10 of 11 industry sectors in positive territory. Only energy stocks are in the red after oil prices slumped overnight. Wall Street ended its three-day losing streak. Bloomberg The Reserve Bank announces its interest rate decision at 2.30pm AEDT today, with markets predicting rise of 0.25 percentage point in the cash rate, which would be the first hike in more than two years. The Australian dollar was trading at US69.69¢ at 12.30pm AEDT. Mining stocks bounced higher, with gold miners Northern Star (up 3.6 per cent) and Evolution Mining (up 5.2 per cent) clawing back some of Monday’s heavy losses as gold and silver prices were again in focus overnight. Gold prices rose 1.8 per cent while silver prices climbed 5.9 per cent. BHP jumped 2 per cent while Rio Tinto surged 2.6 per cent and Fortescue climbed 0.8 per cent. South32 rose 2.3 per cent.

Advertisement

Related Article Opinion

Scandal Why this charismatic corporate salesman’s reign came to an end Elizabeth Knight Business columnist Financial stocks shed some early gains but remain solidly in the green, with Commonwealth Bank rising 0.6 per cent, Westpac up 0.9 per cent, National Australia Bank climbing 0.7 per cent and ANZ Bank advancing 0.6 per cent in early trade. Macquarie Group rose 2.2 per cent. Energy stocks are mixed as oil prices steadied this morning after dropping more than 4 per cent overnight after US President Donald Trump told reporters that Iran is “seriously talking to us.” It’s a potential signal of improving relations between the two countries, which could keep oil flowing easily around the world. Woodside Energy edged up 0.2 per cent, Santos lost 0.3 per cent and Yancoal rose 0.5 per cent. In other news, Elon Musk’s SpaceX has acquired xAI, in a deal that encompasses the billionaire’s increasingly costly ambitions to dominate artificial intelligence and space exploration. The transaction was announced in a statement on SpaceX’s website signed by Musk and confirming an earlier Bloomberg News report. The deal, which gives the combined company a valuation of $US1.25 trillion ($1.8 trillion), was announced to employees in a memo on Monday, Bloomberg News reported earlier.

Advertisement

Overnight on Wall Street, the S&P 500 added 0.5 per cent and snapped a three-day losing streak. The Dow Jones rose 515 points, or 1.1 per cent, and the Nasdaq composite gained 0.6 per cent. Related Article Opinion

Federal Reserve Trump’s hand-picked man may not do his bidding Stephen Bartholomeusz Senior business columnist Elsewhere, the US and India reached a trade agreement cutting tariffs on Indian goods, Donald Trump announced, deescalating tensions between the two countries. Trump said Monday that he would lower his 25 per cent tariff on Indian goods to 18 per cent after Prime Minister Narendra Modi agreed during a phone call to stop buying Russian oil. On Wall Street, Sandisk leaped 15.4 per cent to lead the S&P 500. The data-storage company added to its 6.9 per cent gain from Friday, after it reported stronger profit for the latest quarter than analysts expected. It credited demand created by the artificial-intelligence boom, among other things. That helped offset a 2.9 per cent drop for Nvidia, whose chips are powering much of the world’s move into AI technology.

title: The best places to stay in Cairns
text:
Advertisement

InspirationCairns The best places to stay in Cairns Angela Saurine Updated February 3, 2026 — 12:42pm ,first published July 12, 2023 — 11:21am Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

This article is part of Traveller’s Destination Guide to Cairns. See all stories .

A $600 million investment has transformed this Far North Queensland gateway to the Great Barrier Reef. Long known as a backpacker town, Cairns’ cool factor has skyrocketed in recent years. A $600 million investment by Syrian billionaire Ghassan Aboud, who’s opened three slick and sustainable Crystalbrook Collection hotels in the city since 2018, gave the city a much-needed boost, with many other revamps and refurbishments following in their wake. CAIRNS Novotel Cairns Oasis Resort Get into the holiday groove at Novotel Cairns Oasis Resort.

Advertisement

Perfect for: Families with young kids, leisure seekers, business travellers Sign up for the Traveller Deals newsletter Get exclusive travel deals delivered straight to your inbox. Sign up now. With the only swim-up pool bar in Cairns and a large, lagoon-style pool with a sandy beach, it’s easy to slip into the holiday groove at this refurbished resort. Kids quickly make friends playing with the supplied beach toys, while parents lie back in a cabana or on a day bed sipping mojitos and margaritas. The resort underwent a multi-million-dollar transformation in 2019, refreshing its 314 rooms and suites, plus Moku Bar and Grill restaurant and Moku Beach Club. From $220 a night. 122 Lake St, Cairns. Phone: (07) 4080 1888. See novotelcairnsresort.com.au Crystalbrook Riley Riley’s 1000-square-metre lagoon pool.

Advertisement

Perfect for: Instagrammers, eco-conscious travellers, families The first of three cool and sustainably focused Crystalbrook Collection hotels to open in Cairns – followed by the arty Bailey and fun and centrally located Flynn – this luxury hotel’s 12-storey tower is instantly recognisable on the city skyline. Its 1000-square-metre pool with a man-made beach makes it a great option for families. Dine on the Esplanade at its Asian fusion restaurant, Paper Crane; soak up the vibe at tropical rum bar and seafood kitchen Calypso Club, and take in the sensational views from one of the city’s highest rooftop bars, Rocco. From $349 a night. 131/141 Esplanade, Cairns. Phone: (07) 4252 7777. See crystalbrookcollection.com/riley Mercure Cairns This budget-friendly resort is made for the tropics.

Advertisement

Perfect for: Budget-conscious travellers who like a splash of style This stylish four-star hotel is within cooee of several key attractions, including Cairns Aquarium and Cairns Performing Arts Centre, just a couple of blocks back from the Esplanade. The one-time Hotel Ibis Styles reopened in early 2022 after a stylish makeover, with its Queenslander-style architecture and cane furniture with palm-print cushions in the lobby quickly evoking a feeling of being in the tropics. The 75-room hotel’s tiered pool and tiled deck, complete with round wicker day-beds, is an inviting place to rejuvenate after a day’s sightseeing. From $179 a night. 15 Florence St, Cairns. Phone: (07) 4051 5733. See all.accor.com Shangri-La The Marina, Cairns As close as it gets … Shangri-La, The Marina overlooks Marlin Marina.

Advertisement

Perfect for: Families and couples heading to the reef, solo travellers, business travellers As the closest accommodation you can get to Marlin Marina – where boats depart for the Great Barrier Reef – you can confidently hit the snooze button at least once before a must-do day trip when staying at this hotel. Many of its 255 rooms and suites offer views over the marina or Trinity Inlet, as does its produce-focused restaurant, The Backyard. There’s also a pool with a sun deck and a bar serving meals in biodegradable and recyclable cardboard packaging. From $250. Pier Point Rd, Cairns. Phone: (07) 4052 7500. See shangri-la.com Cairns Harbourside Hotel Great value on the Esplanade … The Cairns Harbourside Hotel.

Advertisement

Perfect for: Families on a budget, business travellers When it comes to affordability and location, this hotel on Cairns Esplanade is hard to beat. The former Holiday Inn is just five minutes’ drive from the airport, and about 25 minutes’ walk along the boardwalk into the centre of town – or you can jump on the free shuttle bus. Each of its 173 rooms and suites has a balcony, and there’s a pool and a fresh, flower-filled restaurant, Harbourside Bar & Kitchen. And as a bonus for families, kids 12 and under stay and eat for free. From $180 a night. 209-217 Esplanade, Cairns. Phone: (07) 4080 3000. See cairnsharboursidehotel.com.au Little Drifter Cairns A bunk room at Little Drifter Cairns.

Advertisement

Perfect for: Budget-conscious travellers After a multimillion-dollar revamp in early 2025, Little Drifter brings a smart and affordable stay close to the action. Previously known as The Village Cairns, the 54-room property, offers a mix of smart dorm-style digs and stylish private rooms. Interiors lean playful and punchy, with communal spaces designed for connection and relaxation. There’s a fully equipped kitchen, a cosy TV lounge, laundry facilities and free Wi-Fi add to its appeal. From $60 a night for a shared bunk suite and $150 per night for a private queen room. 1/7 Shields St, Cairns. Phone: 1800 180 288. See thedrifter.com/cairns Alivio Hotel Cairns The revamped pool deck area at Alivio Hotel Cairns.

Advertisement

Perfect for: Style-seekers wanting fresh, eco-friendly luxury Cairns’ long-standing Sunshine Tower Hotel has been reborn as the Alivio Hotel Cairns following a top-to-toe refurbishment by the award-winning Alivio Group. The 61-room property on Sheridan Street now sports a fresh, contemporary look, complete with a Mediterranean-inspired pool surrounded by flowering frangipanis. The lobby and dining area showcase photographic feature walls that capture the spirit of Tropical North Queensland. Rooms offer views across the hinterland or the manicured gardens, with new glass balustrades adding a modern edge to private balconies. The Lobby Bar and Kitchen serves up light fare and cocktails in a relaxed setting. Sustainability has also had a moment, with the installation of a 100kW solar system. From $199. 136 Sheridan St, Cairns. Phone: (07) 4041 1133. See aliviohotelcairns.com.au BIG4 Ingenia Holidays Cairns Coconut Resort BIG4 Ingenia Holidays Cairns Coconut Resort’s playground and water park.

Advertisement

Perfect for: Fun-loving families

The kids will love racing each other down dual waterslides into the pool, frolicking in the splash park and riding pedal carts around this epic holiday park, around seven minutes’ drive from Cairns. The pet-friendly holiday park offers accommodation for every budget, including villas, cabins, condos and caravan and camping sites. With resort-style pools, a playground, jumping pillows, mini golf, basketball court, tennis court and activities like outdoor movies, you’ll have to drag the offspring away to see the Great Barrier Reef. From $149 a night. 23-51 Anderson Rd, Woree. Phone (07): 4054 6644. See ingeniaholidays.com.au PORT DOUGLAS Silky Oaks Lodge One of the bedrooms at Silky Oaks Lodge. Tourism and Events Queensland

Advertisement

Perfect for: A romantic getaway or special celebration Imagine swaying in a hammock on the deck of your private villa listening to the sounds of the Daintree Rainforest. Or soaking in your outdoor bath as you gaze out at the treetops. Or watching the trickling waters of the Mossman River from the open-air pavilion Jungle Perch as you enjoy a sunset drink before dining in the Treehouse Restaurant. These are the kind of experiences you can expect at this uber-luxury retreat at Mossman, north of Port Douglas. From $1200 a night. 423 Finlayvale Rd, Mossman. Phone: (07) 4098 1666. See silkyoakslodge.com.au Sheraton Grand Mirage Resort Port Douglas Two hectares of saltwater lagoon pools ... Sheraton Grand Mirage Resort in Port Douglas.

Advertisement

Perfect for: Influencers out to impress on the ‘gram, families, couples Offering luxe experiences like the chance to step straight out of the pool onto the balcony of your room, a stay at this beachfront resort can feel more like being in Bali or the Maldives than Australia. Set among tropical gardens with its own golf course, the 295-room resort has a swim-up bar, a restaurant where you can watch your dinner being prepared in the open kitchen and a multi-award-winning Harrisons Restaurant. From $385 a night. 168-190 Port Douglas Rd, Port Douglas. Phone: (07) 4099 5888. See marriott.com Thala Beach Nature Reserve Eco accommodation among the trees at Thala Beach Nature Reserve.

Advertisement

Perfect for: Nature-loving couples, special-occasion trips Embrace your inner naturalist with a stay among the treetops at this eco-retreat, about an hour’s drive north of Cairns and 15 minutes’ south of Port Douglas. Set on a former sugar cane farm with its own private beach and two free-form pools with rock waterfalls and grottos, it offers bungalow accommodation, with an open-air pavilion-style restaurant. Busy yourself with butterfly and nature walks and stargazing tours, or just lie in a hammock under a palm tree. From $562 a night. 5078 Captain Cook Hwy, Oak Beach, Port Douglas. Phone: (07) 4098 5700. See thalabeach.com.au PALM COVE The Reef House Adults Retreat Palm Cove

Advertisement

Relax in the Tranquillity pool, serviced by a pool butler. Perfect for: Girls’ getaways, couples, wellness seekers, foodies Once the private residence of former federal minister Brigadier David Thomson, who hosted high-profile guests such as prime minister Gough Whitlam, this colonial-style, adults-only hotel is in the laid-back enclave of Palm Cove, around 30 minutes’ drive north of Cairns. Start the day with beachfront yoga, book a spa treatment, do a cocktail-making or wine-appreciation class, or just chill out by the Mineral or Tranquillity pools, where a pool butler delivers cold towels and sorbet. From $1029 for two. 99 Williams Esplanade, Palm Cove. Phone: (07) 4080 2600. See reefhouse.com.au Pullman Palm Cove Sea Temple Resort and Spa

Advertisement

The expansive lagoon pool at the Pullman Palm Cove Sea Temple Resort and Spa. Perfect for: Couples, families, spa lovers Set around an expansive pool with an even more inviting bar at the southern end of Palm Cove, this stylish resort makes an idyllic base for a tropical escape. Families love the modern, spacious apartments, while couples unwind with indulgent treatments at Vie Spa, romantic beach strolls and fire-lit dinners at poolside eatery Temple of Tastes, where Asian-inspired dishes are expertly crafted with fresh local produce. From $299 a night. 5 Triton St, Palm Cove. Phone: (07) 4059 9600. See pullmanpalmcove.com.au ISLANDS

Advertisement

Fitzroy Island Resort This affordable island resort is just a 45-minute boat ride from Cairns. Perfect for: Conservation-minded holidaymakers, budget-conscious families, groups of friends Pssst … want to know a secret? There’s an affordable resort on a tropical island just a 45-minute boat ride from Cairns with one of the most beautiful patches of sand you are ever likely to come across, Nudey Beach (not to be taken literally). The island is also home to a turtle rehabilitation centre, and guests can book citizen science tours with marine biologists and see coral nurseries being grown to help restore the Great Barrier Reef just offshore. From $185 a night. Fitzroy Island, Queensland. Phone: (07) 4044 6700. See fitzroyisland.com

Advertisement

Bedarra Island Resort One of the Pavilion villas with private plunge pool at Bedarra Island Resort. Perfect for: Honeymooners, privacy-seeking couples, luxury lovers Secluded, serene and strictly adults-only, Bedarra Island Resort is the epitome of barefoot luxury. The only resort on the island, just off the coast of Mission Beach, the boutique, all-inclusive property has just 12 private villas built around natural boulders overlooking the Coral Sea. Spend your days snorkelling in the stinger-free waters, paddling to private beaches and enjoying intimate dinners on private decks. But while it’s super exclusive, it’s also highly social, with guests gathering around a circular table at the bar for pre-dinner drinks each night. From $1690 a night. Bedarra Island. Phone: (07) 4068 8233. See bedarra.com.au

Advertisement

Lizard Island Resort All-inclusive luxury … Lizard Island Resort. Perfect for: Honeymooners, cashed-up nature lovers, baby boomers spending the kids’ inheritance This exclusive resort on Lizard Island at the northern end of the Great Barrier Reef is the stuff dreams are made of. It has 40 suites and villas – some with their own plunge pool – and a fine-dining waterfront restaurant. Order a hamper, borrow a dinghy and motor to a private beach for a picnic lunch, climb to Cook’s Lookout to take in the panoramic views, and check out the Australian Museum Lizard Island Research Station. From $2516 for two per night. Lizard Island, Queensland. Phone: 1800 867 169. See lizardisland.com.au

Advertisement

The Elandra Mission Beach The clifftop pool at The Elandra. Related Article Cairns The best places to stay in Cairns Perfect for: Boutique lovers, couples, destination wedding guests, privacy seekers Set high above the Coral Sea on a rainforest-cloaked hill, The Elandra on South Mission Beach is a dreamy tropical hideaway just a short drive from the hideaway of Mission Beach, about two hours’ drive south of Cairns. Once a glamorous celebrity haunt that fell into disrepair, the resort has been lovingly revived by the owners of Bedarra Island Resort. It now offers just a handful of beautifully refurbished, whitewashed suites. Days begin with yoga and end by the dazzling infinity pool, cocktail in hand. It’s intimate, exclusive and effortlessly chic – perfect for romantic getaways or show-stopping destination weddings. From $590 a night. 23 Explorers Dr, South Mission Beach. Phone: (07) 4054 9300. See elandraresorts.com
